recentcontent.title: The young, anxious Indian millennial
recentcontent.summary: In 2018, I started conducting research for my book on the economic aspirations, social views, and political attitudes of Indian millennials. My mission was simple. I wanted to understand the views of those we didn’t hear much from. How do young Indians in the country’s small towns and cities view their place in India’s future?

recentcontent.title: Why India’s most aspirational generation — its millennials — is quickly becoming its most anxious one
recentcontent.summary: It was November 2018 in Jabalpur, Madhya Pradesh. I was at the city’s famous Russel Chowk, talking to young people gathered there in the evening. Cars were honking and young men in bright polyester shirts with elaborately coiffed hair and multicoloured sunglasses were racing on their two-wheelers. The air, quickly cooling down, smelled of diesel and dust.

allcontent.title: What do millennials want? Vivan Marwaha’s debut work of non-fiction tries to decode a generation’s prospects
allcontent.summary: Globally, millennials are a contradictory and fascinating bunch – known as much for their love for authenticity as avocados. In India, they constitute a whopping 440 million people, born between 1981 and 1996, making them the largest group of millennials on the planet. And according to Vivan Marwaha’s book, What Millennials Want, this generation – the one that came of age in post-liberalization India, that grew up with Doordarshan and remembers Shah Rukh Khan’s debut as on the TV show Fauji – holds the key to the country’s technological, economic and political future. Yet, we know surprisingly little about this key demographic.

allcontent.title: Books: A millennial writes about millennials
allcontent.summary: Growing up, I remember the “our generation was different from yours” comment being thrown at me by my family. When I told my mom I’d have a love marriage, she would say, “Oh, in my time, I didn’t even have the guts to speak with boys in our school openly.” And when I spent my first internship paycheck taking my family for a dinner, my grandpa had said, “Your generation is imprudent, not saving money when required.”
